item.title: Too Like the Lightning
item.description: Of course I’m immediately starting all over again after [[books/perhaps the stars|Perhaps The Stars]]. Every time, tingling chills down my spine on page 254:

item.title: Seven Surrenders
item.description: There’s no way I can talk comprehensively about this series, so for now I’m just going to keep a running list of different things I notice each time I read them.

item.title: The Will to Battle
item.description: Reader, I cried like Mycroft Canner. It’s very much the first half of a whole (third quarter of four?), and it needs [[books/perhaps the stars|the last book]] to be complete, but what a feat it is on its own.

item.title: Perhaps the Stars
item.description: I still haven’t found the words to talk about this one. Maybe next year I will. It should be in the Smithsonian, or win the Nobel prize, or something, as one of humanity’s greatest achievements.

item.title: Juliette
item.description: I rarely do this, but there’s another review that says it so well, I’m going to quote it instead of trying to sum up my own thoughts:

item.title: Justine, Philosophy in the Bedroom, and Other Writings
item.description: Thank you, [[authors/ada palmer|Ada Palmer]]. I had my suspicions about Sade, that more was going on than just some shock and awe erotica, and in [[books/too like the lightning|Too Like The Lightning]], when he becomes part of the dialogue in a key way, she makes it clear that to read Sade as sadism is too narrow a view.

item.title: Kushiel’s Dart
item.description: My semi-decennial attempt to finish this book. I made it farther this time, with determination, but despite an attempt every three to five years, I still bounce off it like a rubber ball.

item.title: Orlando Furioso
item.description: A note on translation: I used Reynolds to compare, contrast, and fill in the gaps with the [[books/orlando furioso a new verse translation|Slavitt translation]].

item.title: Orlando Furioso: A New Verse Translation
item.description: Ariosto writing like AO3 was a thing in the sixteenth century. I love it. Fiendishly clever layers of satire; a story where anything goes.

item.title: Racing to You
item.description: “Has someone written a romance about pro cycling?” was something I wondered last week. And voila, this book. It actually:

item.title: The Autobiography of Benvenuto Cellini
item.description: Necromancy, assassinations, prison breaks, poisonings, stabbings (so many stabbings!!), pranks on Michelangelo… dude lived a life. Come for the adventure, stay for the fascinating glimpse into Renaissance life and art.

item.title: The Black Jersey
item.description: It takes until page 280 for the main character to say, “I am an imbecile,” which is the truest thing in the book.

item.title: The Cyclist and His Shadow
item.description: I like how right away, in the forward, Thomazeau François is pitting this book against [[books/the rider|The Rider]] as the seminal classic of cycling literature.

item.title: The Rider
item.description: My dear friend Karen made sure I got this book for an October gift, and since pro cycling is currently trying to do a nine month season in two months, including three grand tours, why not pile on some more and make this my cycling read of the (Covid-shortened) season?

item.title: Underland
item.description: For to think in deep time can be a means not of escaping our troubled present, but rather of re-imagining it; countermanding its quick greeds and furies with older, slower stories of making and unmaking.
